content.raw:
great, I tested it and was able to launch docker container on the field computer. The process exits immediately as it's only printing out hello world so I was not able to test the stop cmd though.

During testing, I also tried manually launching a docker container with ubuntu trusty and installed ROS. I was able to to talk to the simulator from inside the container by setting `ROS_MASTER_URI=http://192.168.2.1:11311`. We probably want to document this in the tutorial for creating team's Dockerfile.
content.html:
great, I tested it and was able to launch docker container on the field computer. The process exits immediately as it's only printing out hello world so I was not able to test the stop cmd though.

During testing, I also tried manually launching a docker container with ubuntu trusty and installed ROS. I was able to to talk to the simulator from inside the container by setting ROS_MASTER_URI=http://192.168.2.1:11311. We probably want to document this in the tutorial for creating team's Dockerfile.

content.raw:
Thanks again Shane . 
I could finally make it work. I had to change the nodejs code to listen for the exit event instead of the close event for the stopCmd. It seem the timer subprocess would keep main process's streams open and thus the close event wasn't being called until the timer finished.
content.html: Thanks again Shane . I could finally make it work. I had to change the nodejs code to listen for the exit event instead of the close event for the stopCmd. It seem the timer subprocess would keep main process's streams open and thus the close event wasn't being called until the timer finished.

content.raw:
Hmm could the script be exiting when the docker commands fail? Does changing it to a cleanup function on script exit fix the issue?

```
# ...
# Fork command for timeout handling
{
    # Stop the container after 2 minutes
    sleep 120
    echo "TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT"
    docker stop team_container
} &
timer_pid=$!
echo "timer pid: $timer_pid"

function cleanup {
  echo "Cleaning up timer fork"
  kill -SIGKILL $timer_pid
}
trap cleanup EXIT
# ...
```
content.html:
Hmm could the script be exiting when the docker commands fail? Does changing it to a cleanup function on script exit fix the issue?

# ...
# Fork command for timeout handling
{
    # Stop the container after 2 minutes
    sleep 120
    echo "TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT"
    docker stop team_container
} &
timer_pid=$!
echo "timer pid: $timer_pid"

function cleanup {
  echo "Cleaning up timer fork"
  kill -SIGKILL $timer_pid
}
trap cleanup EXIT
# ...

pullrequest.title: aws scripts and src commands related to field computer

content.raw:
Thanks @sloretz. It is wierd, yes. 
The scenario I'm testing is a container that exits immediately when it is run (ie. the docker runs and exits) , so later when this stop script is executed all the docker commands fails saying that "the specified container does not exist" (or a similar msg). In any case, I can see all the echo statement logged in console (but not the TIMEOUTs one). 

It is worth noticing that when I run this from the terminal I see it working as expected. 

 It seems the problem is when run from the cloudsim-sim nodejs code with "process spawn" . The js code is listening for the "close" event from the process , but that event does not come until the timeout fired.
content.html:
Thanks @sloretz. It is wierd, yes. The scenario I'm testing is a container that exits immediately when it is run (ie. the docker runs and exits) , so later when this stop script is executed all the docker commands fails saying that "the specified container does not exist" (or a similar msg). In any case, I can see all the echo statement logged in console (but not the TIMEOUTs one).

It is worth noticing that when I run this from the terminal I see it working as expected.

It seems the problem is when run from the cloudsim-sim nodejs code with "process spawn" . The js code is listening for the "close" event from the process , but that event does not come until the timeout fired.

content.raw:
That's unexpected. I don't see anything wrong with the script. Are you saying it displays `TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT`?

I commented out the docker commands and replaced the wait with a sleep for 5 seconds, and I get the expected output. The script sleeps for 5 seconds and returns.

```
#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Fork command for timeout handling
{
    # Stop the container after 2 minutes
    sleep 120
    echo "TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT"
    docker stop team_container
} &
timer_pid=$!
echo "timer pid: $timer_pid"

# docker kill --signal "SIGINT" team_container 
echo "sent SIGINT signal to 'team_container' container for smooth shutdown"
echo "about to wait for 'team_container' container to stop"
#docker wait team_container
sleep 5
echo "team_container stopped"
# The container stopped after sigint, cancel the timeout fork
kill -SIGKILL $timer_pid
echo "exiting fc_stop_team_docker"
exit 0
```

```
$ ./test.bash 
timer pid: 3066
sent SIGINT signal to 'team_container' container for smooth shutdown
about to wait for 'team_container' container to stop
team_container stopped
exiting fc_stop_team_docker
```

Is it possible the container isn't exiting? During those 120 seconds does `docker ps` show team_container as still running?
content.html:
That's unexpected. I don't see anything wrong with the script. Are you saying it displays TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT?

I commented out the docker commands and replaced the wait with a sleep for 5 seconds, and I get the expected output. The script sleeps for 5 seconds and returns.

#!/usr/bin/env bash

# Fork command for timeout handling
{
    # Stop the container after 2 minutes
    sleep 120
    echo "TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT"
    docker stop team_container
} &
timer_pid=$!
echo "timer pid: $timer_pid"

# docker kill --signal "SIGINT" team_container 
echo "sent SIGINT signal to 'team_container' container for smooth shutdown"
echo "about to wait for 'team_container' container to stop"
#docker wait team_container
sleep 5
echo "team_container stopped"
# The container stopped after sigint, cancel the timeout fork
kill -SIGKILL $timer_pid
echo "exiting fc_stop_team_docker"
exit 0

$ ./test.bash 
timer pid: 3066
sent SIGINT signal to 'team_container' container for smooth shutdown
about to wait for 'team_container' container to stop
team_container stopped
exiting fc_stop_team_docker

Is it possible the container isn't exiting? During those 120 seconds does docker ps show team_container as still running?

content.html: @sloretz , unfortunately it seems that by having this timer, it prevents the script to return immediately even if the docker process was successfully stopped. Eg. I can see all the echos I do in this script, but anyway the script hangs for 120 seconds and then exits. Could you please take a look to see what Im doing wrong ? Thanks in advance!

content.raw:
I think a timeout would be a good idea in case the field computer ignores SIGINT. One way is to fork something that sleeps for the timeout and kills the container afterwards.

```
# Fork some commands for timeout handling
{
    # Stop the container after 5 minutes
    sleep 300
    echo "TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT"
    sudo docker stop team_container
} &
timer_pid=$!

# Do a task that might never return
docker wait team_container

# The container stopped after sigint, cancel the timeout fork
kill -SIGKILL $timer_pid
```
content.html:
I think a timeout would be a good idea in case the field computer ignores SIGINT. One way is to fork something that sleeps for the timeout and kills the container afterwards.

# Fork some commands for timeout handling
{
    # Stop the container after 5 minutes
    sleep 300
    echo "TIMEOUT TIMEOUT TIMEOUT"
    sudo docker stop team_container
} &
timer_pid=$!

# Do a task that might never return
docker wait team_container

# The container stopped after sigint, cancel the timeout fork
kill -SIGKILL $timer_pid
